post_text:
Lowell Public Schools summer meal service has been extended through September 14. However, we wanted to let you know that our 6 meal sites will be closed on Monday, September 7 in observance of Labor Day.

In order to accommodate this closure, students will be able to receive 5 days worth of meals on Friday, September 4 at the following locations:

STEM Academy (43 Highland St.)
11:00-1:00

Greenhalge School (149 Ennel St.)
11:00-11:30

Westminster Village Apartments (1307 Pawtucket Blvd.)
11:45-12:15

Morey School (130 Pine St.)
12:00-12:30

Murkland School (350 Adams St.)
12:00-12:30

Lincoln School (300 Chelmsford St.)
12:45-1:15

When visiting our lunch sites, please remember that the Governor has ordered that everyone must wear a mask or face covering in public spaces.

post_text:
Save the date!

Back to School Orientation for Remote Learning

Attend an orientation to learn more about your school's remote schedule, online learning program, technology distribution, attendance expectations, grading, and more.

The flyers include orientation schedules for each school. Zoom info will be shared soon on the LPS website.

post_text:
The Lowell Public Schools Technology Help Desk will be setting up a service tent Wednesday, September 2 from 9-11am at the Robinson School (outside the main entrance).

This service is available for any students or staff needing help with a device issued by the Lowell Public Schools, or anyone wishing to return the device they borrowed for remote learning.

You do not need to make an appointment. All visitors must wear a mask and bring the device charger.

If you need to reach the Help Desk, please call 978-674-2024, or email helpdesk@lowell.k12.ma.us. A student or staff email account must be used in order to email the Help Desk.

(Please note that devices will not be distributed at the service tent. Your child's school will be reaching out to announce when devices will be distributed for this school year. We'll also provide more details about this on Wednesday.)

We are also pleased to announce that summer meal service has been extended until the school year begins. We will be sharing an updated schedule with you later today.

post_text:
REMINDER: The deadline to submit an opt-in form for in-person instruction for the upcoming school year is TODAY, Thursday, August 27.

If you want a chance to be part of the lottery used to assign the limited in-person seats that are available, you need to submit the form available here: http://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/returntoschoolform

If you miss this deadline, you will be automatically enrolled in remote learning to start the school year.

post_text:
If a family would like to select in-person instruction on campus, they need to opt-in through an application. The application period will be August 19 - August 27, 2020. LPS will post this application form on the district website and will share this form via email and on social media by Wednesday evening (at the latest).

Please remember that you do not have to make a decision on August 19. As long as you make a decision by August 27, you will be eligible for the lottery for in-person instruction. When you sign up during this period has no impact on your lottery status.
text:
If a family would like to select in-person instruction on campus, they need to opt-in through an application. The application period will be August 19 - August 27, 2020. Please remember that you do not have to make a decision on August 19. As long as you make a decision by August 27, you will be eligible for the lottery for in-person instruction. When you sign up during this period has no impact on your lottery status.

post_text:
Do you need any help with your LPS-issued device or need to return a computer you borrowed?

The Lowell Public Schools Technology Help Desk will be setting up a service tent this week at the following times and locations:

* Tuesday, August 18 from 10am until noon at the Robinson Middle School

* Thursday, August 20 from 10am until noon at the STEM Academy

This service is available for any students or staff needing help with a device issued by the Lowell Public Schools, or anyone needing to return the device they borrowed for remote learning. You do not need to make an appointment. All visitors must wear a mask and bring the device charger.

If you need to reach the Help Desk, please call 978-674-2024, or email helpdesk@lowell.k12.ma.us.

A student or staff email account must be used in order to email the Help Desk.

post_text:
Do you need any help with your LPS-issued device or want to return a computer you borrowed?

The Lowell Public Schools Technology Help Desk will be setting up a service tent this week at the following times and locations:

* Tuesday, August 11 from 10am until noon at the Robinson Middle School

* Thursday, August 13 from 10am until noon at the STEM Academy

This service is available for any students or staff needing help with a device issued by the Lowell Public Schools, or anyone wishing to return the device they borrowed for remote learning. You do not need to make an appointment. All visitors must wear a mask and bring the device charger.

If you need to reach the Help Desk, please call 978-674-2024, or email helpdesk@lowell.k12.ma.us.

A student or staff email account must be used in order to email the Help Desk.

post_text:
Reminder: Tonight, Wednesday, August 5 at 6:30pm (Ch. 99, online at https://www.ltc.org/) the School Committee will review a draft of our reopening plan for the fall. This document is included in the School Committee agenda and we are sharing it with you now. ‬

Agenda: https://www.lowellma.gov/AgendaCenter/ViewFile/Agenda/_08052020-1648?html=true

Document: https://www.lowellma.gov/AgendaCenter/ViewFile/Item/13274?fileID=26461

The plan, titled “Maximizing Options for Families: A Safe School Re-opening Plan for Students within the Context of COVID-19”, offers students a choice between full remote learning or full in-person learning. ‬

It is very important to read the report in full, which answers many frequently asked questions from our community forums last week. It is also important to remember the School Committee still needs to approve this document on Wednesday. ‬

When the document has been approved we will share a final copy of our reopening plan and will have it available in multiple languages in addition to English. ‬

post_text:
The Lowell School Committee will be meeting Thursday night, July 30 at 6:30pm. The meeting will be televised live by LTC on Channel 99 and online at www.ltc.org.

Here is the link to the meeting agenda: http://lowellma.gov/AgendaCenter/ViewFile/Agenda/_07302020-1647?html=true

Planning for a safe return to school this fall will be a topic of discussion during this meeting. The following presentations pertaining to this topic are included in the agenda:

* Approval Of Three Schooling Models - Remote, In-Person And Hybrid - As Required By The Department Of Elementary And Secondary Education For Submission On July 31: http://www.lowellma.gov/AgendaCenter/ViewFile/Item/13268?fileID=26395

* Consideration Of Fall Re-Opening Plan That Maximizes Student Safety And Family Choice: http://www.lowellma.gov/AgendaCenter/ViewFile/Item/13227?fileID=26404

Please note that nothing is official yet in terms of a reopening plan. The School Committee still needs to hear these presentations and approve the plan. The official LPS reopening plan will be shared with families in early August.

Monday, July 27 - 5:30-6:30pm
Monday, July 27 - 7-8pm (Spanish)
Tuesday, July 28 - 9-10am

Zoom links are posted on the Lowell Public Schools website: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/reopeningplanningforum

If you are in need of language interpretation, please email community@lowell.k12.ma.us by the day before so that we can make arrangements.

We look forward to receiving your valuable input during these community forums.

text:
Last chance to take the survey before it closes tonight!

***

As we plan for a safe and successful return to school in the fall, it is important that we hear from our families. We would like your feedback on some of the options we can consider putting into place for the upcoming school year.

There is a survey about returning to school that we are encouraging all families to take: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/ReturnToSchoolSurvey

Thank you in advance for providing us with your valuable feedback and taking the survey!

LOWELL.K12.MA.US
Lowell Public School Return to School Parent/Guardian Survey

post_text:
Do you need any help with your LPS-issued device or want to return a computer you borrowed?

The Lowell Public Schools Technology Help Desk will be setting up a service tent this week at the following times and locations:

* Tuesday, July 7 from 10am until noon at the Robinson Middle School

* Thursday, July 9 from 10am until noon at the STEM Academy

This service is available for any students or staff needing help with a device issued by the Lowell Public Schools, or anyone wishing to return the device they borrowed for remote learning. You do not need to make an appointment. All visitors must wear a mask and bring the device charger.

If you need to reach the Help Desk, please call 978-674-2024, or email helpdesk@lowell.k12.ma.us.

A student or staff email account must be used in order to email the Help Desk.

There is a food pantry at the STEM Academy (43 Highland St.) on Tuesday, July 7 from 3-4pm.

This is a farmer’s market style distribution of assorted foods for all Lowell Public School students and their families. Please bring reusable grocery bags, baskets, or a cart to carry your food.

More information on the flyer.

As a reminder, when visiting any of our meal sites, please remember that the Governor has ordered that everyone must wear a mask or face covering in public spaces.

post_text:
Check out this great article in the Lowell Sun about Tsongas Scholarship recipient Amina Bahati, one of the star students from the Lowell High Class of 2020: https://www.lowellsun.com/2020/07/01/from-uganda-to-success-at-lowell-high/

Overcoming obstacles, Amina became a student leader at LHS, serving as vice president of the senior class. Amina was also active in the LHS ROTC, National Honor Society, the Black Unity Club, International Unity Club and the Middlesex Community College TRiO Upward Bound program.

Congratulations Amina!

Did you know that #LowellHigh students can participate in on-campus programs, events, and activities at Middlesex Community College while enrolled in #EarlyCollegeLowell? Students can not only earn up to a year of college credit at no cost to them, but they can also join in on the fun at MCC! Learn more on how you can enroll today - https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/earlycollege

Project LEARN, Inc.

* The STEM Academy from 11am-1pm

* The Westminster Village Apartments from 11:45am-12:15pm

* The Morey School from 12pm-12:30pm

* The Murkland School from 12pm-12:30pm

* The Lincoln School from 12:45pm-1:15pm

When visiting our lunch sites, please remember that the Governor has ordered that everyone must wear a mask or face covering in public spaces.

post_text:
Registration is open for IDEA Camp! This popular summer program is a hands-on, interactive opportunity for middle and high school students to explore topics in the field of STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Mathematics) and apply their learning towards career exploration and college readiness. It is free of charge to attend!

Right now we are planning on holding all summer programs remotely.

Click here for more information and for specific workshop offerings: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/ideacamp

post_text:
Please note that the cutoff deadline to be eligible for the Preschool and Kindergarten lottery is TODAY, Tuesday, June 30, 2020 at noon. After this deadline, students who register for Preschool and Kindergarten will be added to a waitlist and will not be included in the lottery.

Also keep in mind that even if your child is currently enrolled in a Lowell Public Schools Preschool program you still need to register for Kindergarten.

Please read the information on this page to find out more about the online registration process: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/registrationinfo

And, watch this helpful tutorial to guide you through our online registration form: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x2qXn_qQmyc

Here is the link to the registration form: www.lowell.k12.ma.us/registrationform

If you have any further questions about registration, you can call the Family Resource Center at 978-674-4321.

Do you need any help with your LPS-issued device or want to return a computer you borrowed?

The Lowell Public Schools Technology Help Desk will be setting up a service tent this week at the following times and locations:

* Monday, June 29 from 9am until noon at the Bailey Elementary School

* Wednesday, July 1 from 9am until noon at the STEM Academy

* Thursday, July 2 from 9am until noon at the Reilly Elementary School

This service is available for any students or staff needing help with a device issued by the Lowell Public Schools, or anyone wishing to return the device they borrowed for remote learning. You do not need to make an appointment. All visitors must wear a mask and bring the device charger.

If you need to reach the Help Desk, please call 978-674-2024, or email helpdesk@lowell.k12.ma.us.

A student or staff email account must be used in order to email the Help Desk.

Just a reminder that the registration period for Kindergarten and Preschool is now underway (all students entering grades 1-12 who are new to the district can also register now).

Please note that the cutoff deadline to be eligible for the Preschool and Kindergarten lottery is this Tuesday, June 30, 2020 at noon. After this deadline, students who register for Preschool and Kindergarten will be added to a waitlist and will not be included in the lottery.

Also keep in mind that even if your child is currently enrolled in a Lowell Public Schools Preschool program you still need to register for Kindergarten.

Please read the information on this page to find out more about the online registration process: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/registrationinfo

And, watch this helpful tutorial to guide you through our online registration form: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x2qXn_qQmyc

Here is the link to the registration form: www.lowell.k12.ma.us/registrationform

If you have any further questions about registration, you can call the Family Resource Center at 978-674-4321.

post_text:
This looks delicious! Available today at the Morey and Lincoln lunch sites!

Here is where Lowell Public Schools students can go for summer meal service:

* The STEM Academy will have meal service every weekday, Monday through Friday, from 11am - 1pm.

The rest of our sites will be serving only on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays:

* The Greenhalge School from 11am-11:30am

* The Westminster Village Apartments from 11:45am-12:15pm

* The Morey School from 12pm-12:30pm

* The Murkland School from 12pm-12:30pm

* The Lincoln School from 12:45pm-1:15pm

At these sites, students will receive two breakfasts and two lunches on Mondays and Wednesdays and will also receive meals for the weekend days on Fridays. Students at the STEM site will also receive meals for the weekend days on Fridays.

When visiting our lunch sites, please remember that the Governor has ordered that everyone must wear a mask or face covering in public spaces.

Also note that the cutoff deadline to be eligible for the Preschool and Kindergarten lottery is June 30, 2020 at noon. After this deadline, students who register for Preschool and Kindergarten will be added to a waitlist and will not be included in the lottery.

Please read the information on this page to find out more about the online registration process: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/registrationinfo

And, watch this helpful tutorial to guide you through our online registration form: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x2qXn_qQmyc

Here is the link to the registration form: www.lowell.k12.ma.us/registrationform

If you have any further questions about registration, you can call the Family Resource Center at 978-674-4321.

post_text:
Happy Monday! Here is where Lowell Public Schools students can go for summer meal service:

* The STEM Academy will have meal service every weekday, Monday through Friday, from 11am - 1pm.

The rest of our sites will be serving only on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays:

* The Greenhalge School from 11am-11:30am

* The Westminster Village Apartments from 11:45am-12:15pm

* The Morey School from 12pm-12:30pm

* The Murkland School from 12pm-12:30pm

* The Lincoln School from 12:45pm-1:15pm

At these sites, students will receive two breakfasts and two lunches on Mondays and Wednesdays and will also receive meals for the weekend days on Fridays. Students at the STEM site will also receive meals for the weekend days on Fridays.

When visiting our lunch sites, please remember that the Governor has ordered that everyone must wear a mask or face covering in public spaces.

Registration is open for IDEA Camp! This popular summer program is a hands-on, interactive opportunity for middle and high school students to explore topics in the field of STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Mathematics) and apply their learning towards career exploration and college readiness. It is free of charge to attend!

Right now we are planning on holding all summer programs remotely.

Click here for more information and for specific workshop offerings: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/ideacamp

post_text: Today - Monday, June 15, 2020 - marks the last day of the 2019-2020 school year for the Lowell Public Schools! This is definitely an unusual end to the school year, but this shared experience is certainly something we’ll never forget! Thank you to all of the teachers, principals, administrators and staff - and of course our students and families - for working together to make the most of this difficult situation!

post_text:
Exciting news to share! The Lowell Public Schools and the City of Lowell are pleased to announce that the Lowell High School Class of 2020 in-person graduation has been scheduled for July 21st and July 22nd (rain dates of July 23rd and July 24th) at Edward A. LeLacheur Park, which is home to the Lowell Spinners.

In keeping with the health and safety guidance provided by the Governor of Massachusetts and the City of Lowell Health Department, this year’s graduation will take place outdoors, over two days, with two ceremonies scheduled for each day – at 4pm and 7pm. These four small ceremonies over a two-day period will enable Lowell High School students, families and staff to follow social distancing and safety protocols while still providing the opportunity to celebrate a milestone accomplishment in the students’ lives.

Please click here for more details: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/LHS2020Graduation

post_text: Today’s the day! Stop by one of our grab & go lunch sites for a literacy bundle from our friends at Project LEARN, Inc.!
text: Today’s the day! Stop by one of our grab & go lunch sites for a literacy bundle from our friends at Project LEARN, Inc.!

post_text: Check out this info on BookFest from our friends at Project LEARN, Inc.! There will be Literacy Bundles distributed at many of our schools on Friday (June 12). Details on the flyer!
shared_text:
Project LEARN, Inc.
June 8 at 6:54 PM ·

With the end of the school year quickly approaching, we are excited to kickoff #summerliteracy this week with our 4th annual BookFest! We are teaming up with volunteers to distribute 1,000 literacy bundles to Lowell kids on June 12th.

Although this year's event will have a more virtual look, we have put together a schedule of virtual events with help from our amazing partners at Lowell Public Schools, Lowell National Historical Park, and Pollard Memorial Library. Join us for some fun this week!

A special thanks to our amazing partners Lowell Public Schools, Lowell Public Schools Early Childhood Department, Lowell Early Childhood Council (LECC), & Lowell National Historical Park and our premier sponsor and advocate, Eastern Bank!

#Lowelllovestolearn #bookfest #kickofftosummerliteracy

post_text:
We are pleased to announce the three finalists for consideration for the Head of School role at Lowell High School (listed here in alphabetical order): Ian Charles, Michael Fiato, and Sara Pragluski Walsh.

The district will be holding three virtual community forums this week, providing the public with the opportunity to meet each of the finalists and ask questions about their background and vision for Lowell High.

* Tuesday, June 9 from 5pm until 6pm

* Wednesday, June 10 from 5pm until 6pm

* Thursday, June 11 from 5pm until 6pm

Zoom info for each forum can be found here: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/HOSfinalistsforum

If you are interested in asking a question, please submit your question prior to the community forum by emailing community@lowell.k12.ma.us. The deadline to submit a question is Tuesday, June 9, 2020 at noon.

A full bio for each finalist is posted here: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/LowellHighHeadofSchoolFinalistsBio

More info about the search process can be found here: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/LowellHighHeadofSchoolFinalists

The Lowell Public Schools Technology Help Desk will be setting up a service tent this week at the following times and locations:

* Wednesday, June 3 from 10am until noon at the STEM Academy, located at 43 Highland St.

* Thursday, June 4 from 10am until noon at the Morey Elementary School, located at 130 Pine St.

* Friday, June 5 from 10am until noon at the Stoklosa Middle School, located at 560 Broadway St.

This service is available for any students or staff with a device issued by the Lowell Public Schools. You do not need to make an appointment. All visitors must wear a mask and bring the device charger. New devices will not be issued at the service tent. Please contact your school if you still need a device.

If you need to reach the Help Desk, please call 978-674-2024, or email helpdesk@lowell.k12.ma.us.

A student or staff email account must be used in order to email the Help Desk.

post_text:
We have heard from some families that they have submitted the registration form online and did not receive email confirmation. We have reached the limit of automatic emails that can be sent per day. If you have not received an email today, you should receive one tomorrow or the day after at the latest. Be sure to check your spam folder if you don't receive an email within the next couple of days.

It is important to note that you can still register your child today. You just won't get an email confirmation today, but it will come.

Once you receive the email, please be sure to respond and submit the requested documentation promptly. Your child(ren) will not be officially registered until the documentation has been received and reviewed by a clerk at the Family Resource Center.

To find out more about the online registration process, read the information on this page: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/registrationinfo

And, watch this helpful tutorial to guide you through our online registration form: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x2qXn_qQmyc

post_text:
On Memorial Day we remember the men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice for this country while serving in the United States Armed Forces. Did you know that the Shaughnessy Elementary School is named for one of these heroes?

The Shaughnessy Elementary School is named after Lt. John J. Shaughnessy. Lt. Shaughnessy was a resident of Gorham Street (the street where the Shaughnessy School is located), and one of the first residents of Lowell to enlist in World War II. Lt. Shaughnessy gave his life heroically during the Allied Forces’ D-Day Invasion on June 6, 1944.

Watch this video tribute posted on the Shaughnessy School website: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/cms/lib/MA01907636/Centricity/Domain/27/Shaughnessy%20Memorial%20Day%20Message.mp4

post_text:
LOWELL PUBLIC SCHOOLS REGISTRATION INFORMATION FOR THE UPCOMING 2020-2021 SCHOOL YEAR

In order to hold registration in as safe and efficient a manner as possible given the current circumstances, registration will now be done online.

The online registration period for preschool and kindergarten for the upcoming 2020-2021 school year will begin on Tuesday, May 26. All students entering grades 1-12 who are new to the district or who want to transfer into the Lowell Public Schools can also register during this period.

Please read the information on this page to find out more about the online registration process: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/registrationinfo

And, watch this helpful tutorial to guide you through our online registration form: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x2qXn_qQmyc

The Lowell Public Schools IT Help Desk will be setting up a service tent TODAY, Friday, May 22 from 10am until noon at the STEM Academy, located at 43 Highland St.

This service is available for any students or staff with a device issued by the Lowell Public Schools. You do not need to make an appointment. All visitors must wear a mask and bring the device charger. New devices will not be issued at the service tent. Please contact your school if you still need a device.

If you need to reach the Help Desk, please call 978-674-2024, or email helpdesk@lowell.k12.ma.us.

A student or staff email account must be used in order to email the Help Desk.

post_text:
REMINDER: All of the grab and go meal sites will be closed on Memorial Day (Monday, May 25). In order to accommodate this closure, families can visit our meal sites TODAY, Friday, May 22 and will be able to pick up meals for today, the weekend days, and Monday as well.

New at-home learning packets will still be distributed at all of the meal sites today. Since the meal sites are closed on Monday, you will also be able to pick up packets at the meal sites on Tuesday, May 26. The packets include activities that support the remote learning plan and are also posted on the remote learning section of the district website: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/Page/3782

A list of locations and times for our meal service can be found on the district website: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/Page/3776

Please remember that the Governor has ordered that you must wear a mask or face covering in public spaces. Doing so not only helps keep you safe, but helps keep all of our staff safe as well.

post_text:
The 2020 U.S. Census is still happening. It takes 10 minutes to complete the questionnaire and determines how billions of dollars of government funding will flow to Lowell for programs like education, healthcare, and disaster relief for the next decade.

The U.S. Census Bureau is bound by law to protect your answers and keep them confidential.

It has never been easier to respond on your own, whether online, over the phone or by mail—all without having to meet a census taker.

Complete the US Census at 2020Census.Gov. Do your part and respond to the 2020 Census today!

post_text: Passing this message along from the City's Facebook page: If you receive a phone call from a 978-674 number, pick up the phone. It may be a member of the City's contact tracing team. Nurses from the Lowell Health Department contact individuals who have tested positive for COVID-19 and their direct contacts to provide critical info.
shared_text:
City of Lowell, MA - Government is sharing a COVID-19 Update.
May 19 at 8:32 PM ·

If you receive a phone call from a 978-674 number, pick up the phone. It may be a member of the City's contact tracing team.

Nurses from the Lowell Health Department contact individuals who have tested positive for COVID-19 and their direct contacts to provide critical information and to ensure that they have the support and medical attention needed through the quarantine or isolation period.

Contact tracing is a critical public health tool in combatting the spread of COVID-19 and keeping our community safe. Do your part to support this important work by looking out for these calls and cooperating fully if you receive one.

City of Lowell, MA - Government is sharing a COVID-19 Update.
May 19 at 8:32 PM ·

If you receive a phone call from a 978-674 number, pick up the phone. It may be a member of the City's contact tracing team.

Nurses from the Lowell Health Department contact individuals who have tested positive for COVID-19 and their direct contacts to provide critical information and to ensure that they have the support and medical attention needed through the quarantine or isolation period.

Contact tracing is a critical public health tool in combatting the spread of COVID-19 and keeping our community safe. Do your part to support this important work by looking out for these calls and cooperating fully if you receive one.

Last night we sent out a message with the IT Help Desk Service Tent schedule for this week. If you have a child in the Lowell Public Schools, you should have received both a phone call and email between 7:15-7:45pm on Sunday. If you didn't, please fill out this form and make sure we have the most up-to-date phone number and email address so we can update your contact info so you receive all of our messages going forward: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3Md1leOCZiQ2bi2enmSvUXvROSnPVDPTIs9nmIdFPq3wl5Q/viewform

* Please do not post your contact information in the comments section of this post. Filling out the form is the best way to make sure your contact info is securely updated.

post_text:
It is almost time for lunch!

We are offering grab and go meals for Lowell Public Schools students at a total of 11 sites during the weekdays while school buildings are closed: Butler, Greenhalge, Lincoln, Moody, Morey, Murkland, Pawtucketville, Robinson, STEM Academy, Stoklosa and the Westminster Village Apartments.

In addition to picking up that day’s lunch, you will also be able to take home breakfast for the next morning. And, on Fridays, you will be able to pick up meals for the weekend days as well.

New at-home learning packets will also be available on Fridays and Mondays at all of the meal sites. The packets include activities that support the remote learning plan and are also posted on our website: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/Page/3782

REMINDER: If you weren't able to join us Wednesday morning, LPS is sponsoring another session of the COVID-19 parent webinar tonight (Thursday, May 7) from 7pm - 8:15pm. Below is a description and link to register for the Zoom webinar. We hope you will join us!

Sarah Rigney and Alice Barber will present a webinar for any Lowell parents/caregivers who would like to participate. The webinar is called “Parenting in the Time of COVID-19: Is This a Dream?” The session will cover acknowledging and working with big feelings, grief, challenges associated with home-based education, and “good enough parenting” during this extraordinarily challenging time.

---

Thursday, 5/7/20, 7pm - 8:15pm

Please register in advance for this meeting:

https://zoom.us/meeting/register/tJwsdeivqTMvHN2be1SpfFQNtE2G2E6vGtFh

After registering, you will receive a confirmation email containing information about joining the meeting.

post_text:
There is still time to help us say thank you to our teachers!

May 4-8 is Teacher Appreciation Week and while we wish we could be saying thanks in person, we can still celebrate our teachers virtually!

Here is how you can participate and say "thanks"...

We'd like to encourage our students/families to make thank you cards/messages. If you have some time today, make a card or poster, take a picture of it, and email it to jpickette@lowell.k12.ma.us, or message this Facebook page. Be sure to include what school you go to! If there is a specific teacher or teachers you would like to thank, you can do that too! We will share your photos on this Facebook page!

And, on Friday at 3pm, let’s step outside and applaud our teachers together from a distance! Just remember to follow social distancing protocols!

Thanks for your help!

Last Friday was National School Principals' Day, so we want to give some belated recognition to our principals and school leaders as well.

To kick things off, here is a message Superintendent Boyd shared on Twitter this evening:

"Happy #TeacherAppreciationWeek to our amazing teachers who deserve more thx now than maybe ever before - they redesigned the curriculum overnight & have worked nonstop to close the digital divide to bring comfort & a sense of normalcy to our kids. Can’t say it enough: THANK YOU!"

post_text:
It’s not too late to respond to the 2020 Census!

The census counts every person living in the United States, regardless of age or citizenship status, every 10 years in years ending in 0.

The Census helps determine how billions of dollars in federal funding will flow into Lowell. It determines how billions of dollars of government funding will go to programs like healthcare, disaster relief, and our schools for the next 10 years.

In Lowell, we all count. You can complete the 2020 Census by mail, online (2020census.gov), or by phone (844-330-2020).

Your data is protected and it’s confidential. Federal law protects your responses, which cannot be shared with law enforcement, immigration agencies, or housing authorities.

It takes 10 minutes to complete the form. Please note that in the top right corner of the census website (2020census.gov), you can change the language.

Once you have responded, please encourage your family, friends and loved ones to complete the census, too.

post_text:
Hello Lowell Public Schools Parents and Caregivers,

LPS is sponsoring a parent webinar next week on Monday morning, May 4th from 10:30am – 11:15am and on Thursday evening, May 7th from 7:00pm – 8:15pm Below is a description and link to the Zoom Webinar. All you have to do is click on the link at the time of the webinar. We hope you will join us!

Sarah Rigney and Alice Barber will present webinars for any Lowell parents/caregivers who would like to participate. The webinar is called “Parenting in the Time of COVID-19: Is This a Dream?” The session will cover acknowledging and working with big feelings, grief, challenges associated with home-based education, and “good enough parenting” during this extraordinarily challenging time.

---

post_text:
Today, Friday, May 1 has been declared “School Lunch Hero Day.” This is the perfect opportunity to thank the LPSD - Food & Nutrition staff for all of their hard work!

Our school lunch heroes deserve special recognition for stepping up during this unprecedented time, serving nutritious meals to our students even when our buildings are closed!

Be sure to say thank you when you pick up your meals today!

We'll be sharing the cards you have submitted later today on Facebook.

post_text:
There is still time to help us say thank you to our school lunch heroes!

This Friday, May 1 has been declared “School Lunch Hero Day.” This is the perfect opportunity to thank the staff working hard to still serve meals to our students, even when our buildings are closed!

Here is how you can participate and say "thanks"...

We'd like to encourage our students/families to make thank you cards/messages. If you have some time today or tomorrow, make a card or poster, take a picture of it, and email it to jpickette@lowell.k12.ma.us, or message this Facebook page. You can also take a photo of you enjoying a grab and go lunch!

We will share your photos/messages tomorrow!

Thanks for your help!

Lowell Public Schools Early Childhood Department
April 27 at 3:27 PM ·

Parenting during quarantine getting you overwhelmed? Are you looking for ideas and strategies about how to parent in preventive and positive ways? Would you like to meet other families with young children (1- 8 years old) who are also sharing this parenting journey?
Join LPS leader Darcie as we learn together through the 6-week "Positive Solutions" parenting series. Classes start this Thursday, April 30th from 6-7pm on Zoom.
Register by emailing dcoleman@lowell.k12.ma.us for the Zoom ID and password.

Are you a young person concerned about the impact of COVID-19 on yourself and your community? Massachusetts Department of Public Health is hosting a town hall on Thursday April 30th from 2pm-3pm. It will be an interactive opportunity for you to ask medical professionals and statisticians questions about COVID-19 and talk to teens across The Commonwealth about ways to keep your communities safe.

Please register here https://zoom.us/meeting/register/tJUkdO-vrjgpGNY7HhNg1MAGy3LfcjnVwO7c

post_text:
Rain or shine (today definitely falls under the rain category), we are offering grab and go meals for Lowell Public Schools students at a total of 11 sites during the weekdays while school buildings are closed: Butler, Greenhalge, Lincoln, Moody, Morey, Murkland, Pawtucketville, Robinson, STEM Academy, Stoklosa and the Westminster Village Apartments.

In addition to picking up that day’s lunch, you will also be able to take home breakfast for the next morning. And, on Fridays, you will be able to pick up meals for the weekend days as well.

New at-home learning packets will also available on Fridays and Mondays at all of the meal sites. The packets include activities that support the remote learning plan and are also posted on our website: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/Page/3782

post_text:
Wanted to share this idea from the S. Christa McAuliffe Elementary School...

"Bear About Lowell" is a fun activity for the families of the Lowell Community and the students of Lowell Public Schools to engage in during an unprecedented time of remote learning and social distancing.

It starts by watching Ms. Coleman from the Lowell Public Schools Early Childhood Department read the book "Bear About Town" ... Here is the link to the video: https://youtu.be/eCJj65SpOkk

Once you've read the book with Ms. Coleman, you are ready to participate! Check out all of the activities on this website: https://sites.google.com/view/bear-about-lowell/home?fbclid=IwAR22qWAkTNXku21xHGKzQlrXYM4aHsFySL9fLEtlLBHaEK6F65StbbPb54g

Or, check out the flyers on this Facebook post and participate in the activities that are appropriate for your families!
shared_text:
S. Christa McAuliffe Elementary School
April 21 at 4:45 PM ·

Now that you've heard Ms. Coleman's reading of "Bear About Town," here are 2 ways to participate in Bear About Lowell! Take your own bear on a scavenger hunt or take this tally sheet to see how many bears you can find in your neighborhood! For all of the resources go to: https://sites.google.com/view/bear-about-lowell/home #McAuliffeRocks

This is a great way to phrase the current situation! Sharing this post from the S. Christa McAuliffe Elementary School Facebook page:

“School is NOT closed for the school year. The building is.”

Remote learning instruction will continue for the rest of the school year. Meal service will continue for all families in need.

We will still be here for our students and families!

April 21 at 5:39 PM ·

post_text:
Governor Baker just announced that all schools in Massachusetts, including the Lowell Public Schools, will now be closed for the remainder of the school year. We will continue with our remote learning instruction for the rest of the school year.

From Superintendent Boyd on Twitter: The Lowell Public Schools “was prepared for this possibility. An additional 1000 chromebooks will be distributed this week & meal service will continue for all families in need. Our amazing staff is rising to the occasion & we will make it thru this unprecedented time together as #OneLowell.”

More details will follow.

post_text:
In case you missed it, the state has canceled MCAS testing scheduled for this spring.

Here is the latest from the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE):

The Department previously requested and received a waiver from the federal requirement for annual statewide student assessment. Now, with the state legislation enacted, the MCAS testing requirement is waived for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. As a result of these federal and state actions and in light of the on-going health crisis, Commissioner Riley has canceled this spring’s regular administration of grade-level MCAS tests for students in grades 3-10. In addition, the legislation allows the Board of Elementary and Secondary Education, upon the commissioner’s recommendation, to modify or waive the requirements of the competency determination for high school graduation in order to address disruptions caused by the outbreak of COVID-19 or the state of emergency. The commissioner is considering various options, and further guidance will be forthcoming.

The commissioner is considering various options, and further guidance will be forthcoming.

shared_text:
City of Lowell, MA - Government
April 13 at 6:59 PM ·

The City of Lowell has opened an emergency shelter in the gymnasium of the Stoklosa Middle School, located at 560 Broadway Street. The shelter will accommodate asymptomatic individuals experiencing homelessness that have been exposed to individuals who have tested positive for COVID-19. No individuals who have tested positive will be directed to the Stoklosa site.

The emergency shelter is intended to support the mitigation of the risk of a COVID-19 outbreak within the population served by the existing shelter. Its opening comes following extensive planning untaken by the City in partnership with Southern Middlesex Opportunity Council (SMOC) and the Lowell Community Health Center to address the distinct vulnerability that the coronavirus crisis poses to individuals experiencing homelessness.

Click here for more details: https://www.lowellma.gov/DocumentCenter/View/11405/PRESS-RELEASE-City-of-Lowell-Opens-Emergency-Shelter_413?bidId=

shared_text:
City of Lowell, MA - Government
April 7 at 12:43 AM ·

On Tuesday, April 7, CVS Health will launch the operation of a rapid COVID-19 testing site in Lowell, the first of its kind in the state. The drive-through site will offer no-cost testing to Massachusetts residents and will be capable of conducting and processing up to 1,000 tests per day.

Testing operations will be conducted from the parking lot of Lowell's Showcase Cinema, located at 32 Reiss Ave and accessible from Route 110 and Industrial Avenue.

Through the use of recently FDA authorized Abbott ID NOW COVID-19 testing, results will be produced in in an average of fifteen minutes, enabling patients to be informed of the results before departing the site. The on-the-spot results produced through this method will allow healthcare professionals to advise patients on appropriate treatment instantaneously.

Read more: https://www.lowellma.gov/DocumentCenter/View/11365/CVS-Partners-with-City-and-State-to-Launch-Rapid-Site_4620?bidId=

post_text:
Because of the long-term closure of all schools in Massachusetts, the state has asked all schools to implement a remote learning program.

Nothing can take the place of the daily in-person interactions that our teachers have with our students. But, until we are able to return to school, we are prepared to offer our students a meaningful and engaging learning experience that also accounts for the pressures that families and staff are encountering during this pandemic.

We have emailed you a copy of the letter detailing this remote learning plan. We have also posted the letter on the district website and on the district’s social media pages: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/Page/3868

After reading this letter, we anticipate that there will be many questions as we transition to this remote learning plan over the next week. Your child’s school and teachers will be guiding you through this process and will be reaching out to you with more specific details. As always, you can contact the Family Resource Center by calling 978-674-4321.

post_text:
Today is National Census Day. It’s time to be counted. The Census helps determine how billions of dollars in federal funding will flow into Lowell. It takes 10 minutes to complete the form and determines how billions of dollars of government funding will go to programs like healthcare, disaster relief, and our schools for the next 10 years.

In Lowell, we all count. You can complete the 2020 Census by mail, online (2020census.gov), or by phone.

#2020Census #lowellcounts

post_text:
BREAKFAST AND LUNCH IS AVAILABLE: We are providing breakfast and lunch for students during the weekdays at nine sites while school is closed: Bartlett, Butler, Greenhalge, Lincoln, Moody, Murkland, Pawtucketville, Robinson, and STEM (Rogers). There will be a truck on location at each site with meals available to pickup and take home. Families will be able to pick up lunch as well as take home breakfast for the following morning. Please click here for full details on locations and times: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/Page/3776

All students ages 2-18 are eligible for this program. Students don’t have to be present to pick up a meal. A parent or neighbor can pick up the student’s meal.

We want to clarify and make sure you know that the emergency order requiring non-essential businesses to close and the stay-at-home advisory DON'T impact our meal service.

Lowell Public Schools students will still be able to pick up breakfast and lunch during the weekdays while school is closed at each of the 9 sites we have been operating.

Click here for more details about our grab and go meal service: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/Page/3776

post_text:
As you may have seen, Governor Baker issued an emergency order today requiring non-essential businesses and organizations to close. He also issued a stay-at-home advisory. Both of these measures are effective from March 24 at noon until April 7.

We want to clarify and make sure you know that this does not impact our meal service. Lowell Public Schools students will still be able to pick up breakfast and lunch during the weekdays while school is closed at each of the 9 sites we have been operating.

Click here for more details about our grab and go meal service: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/Page/3776

post_text:
Good morning, Lowell! Per Governor Baker’s order, the Lowell Public Schools will continue to be closed until Monday, April 6, 2020.

As we start week 2 of our closure, here is a reminder to check our COVID-19 info page: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/Page/3773

This is where you will find the latest updates, including information about grab and go meals and learning opportunities at home.

We will also keep you updated on a regular basis on both Facebook and Twitter, in addition to our website.

post_text: What a great idea! Check out this video from the Pyne Arts Magnet School and make sure to check out our virtual read aloud YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCMIqoXopDU-6yfq5pJIPRtg
shared_text:

Sing Along with Principal Roberge

Pyne Arts Magnet School
March 20 at 9:41 PM ·

Hi Pyne Arts! I've seen a lot of book read aloud videos out there, but I wanted to do my part to keep the arts alive while we are out of school. Join me on YouTube for a sing along! My voice is a bit rusty- it's been a long time since I've done any singing- but I hope you just have fun with it like I did. Have a great weekend!

To support literacy at home, we have launched a YouTube channel devoted to posting virtual read-alouds by teachers and principals across the district. See our educators reading their favorite books to help our students stay engaged while schools are closed.

Here is a video of Shaughnessy Elementary School Principal Mr. Passeri (and his son Andrew) reading Goodnight Moon: https://youtu.be/uyGe8L0hseQ

You can access the YouTube channel by searching for “Lowell Public Schools Virtual Read Alouds” on YouTube, or by clicking here: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCMIqoXopDU-6yfq5pJIPRtg/

It might be cold outside, but we are still providing grab and go lunches for Lowell Public Schools students! We will be at 9 sites during the weekdays while school is closed.

Bartlett (11-11:30am)
79 Wannalancit St.

Butler (12:45-1:30pm)
1140 Gorham St.

Greenhalge (10:30-11am)
149 Ennell St.

Lincoln (1:30-2pm)
300 Chelmsford St.

Moody (12-12:30pm)
158 Rogers St.

Murkland (12:45-1:15pm)
350 Adams St.

Pawtucketville (12-12:30pm)
425 West Meadow Rd.

Robinson (11:15-11:45am)
110 June St.

STEM Academy/Rogers* (10:30am-1 pm)
43 Highland St.

*STEM meal service will be available at back door at the kitchen loading dock area off South St.

All students ages 2-18 are eligible for this lunch program. Given the circumstances, students don’t have to be present to pick up a meal. A parent or neighbor can pick up the student’s lunch.

post_text:
Please read the following letter from Superintendent of Schools Dr. Joel Boyd: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/cms/lib/MA01907636/Centricity/Domain/2728/LPSD%20COVID-19%20Update%203-16-20.pdf

This letter provides several important updates including the following items of note:

*Governor Baker has declared that all schools in Massachusetts will close for the next three weeks.

*We will now offer lunch for Lowell Public Schools students at a total of nine sites during the weekdays.

*We have delayed both preschool and kindergarten registration periods and will provide you with more details once new dates have been finalized.

*As of Tuesday, March 17, both the Central Office and Family Resource Center (FRC) will be closed to the public, with all staff working remotely.

post_text:
Good morning, Lowell Public Schools families!

We wanted to check in with you and let you know that even though school is closed for the next 3 weeks, we will be in regular contact with you throughout this situation. Important updates and messages will be shared on this Facebook page, as well as the Lowell Public Schools website.

Here are a few important Notes this Monday morning:

* Governor Baker announced that schools in this state will be closed for the next 3 weeks.

* We will now be offering lunch for Lowell Public Schools students at a total of 9 sites during the weekdays while school is closed. Please see the flyer for details.

* Preschool and kindergarten registration has been postponed due to school being closed. We will let you know when new dates for registration have been finalized.

* The Knowledge Bowl finals were scheduled for tonight (March 16) and have been postponed. We will let you know when the finals will be held once a new date has been finalized.

post_text:
Due to evolving concerns related to the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19), the City of Lowell has announced that it will be closing City Hall and all other City buildings to the public beginning Monday, March 16, 2020 until further notice.

At this time, all City of Lowell employees will continue to report to work, and departments will remain open. The City intends to maintain essential functions and services at full capacity. The public will be able to contact all departments by phone and e-mail.

Read the full announcement here: https://www.lowellma.gov/DocumentCenter/View/11022/PRESS-RELEASE-Lowell-City-Hall-and-All-City-Buildings-to-Close-to-Public_31320?bidId=

post_text:
Knowledge Bowl update!

We've had 2 semifinal round matches so far this week. Congrats to the Wang Middle School and the Stoklosa Middle School for advancing to the finals!

Who will join them? There is one semifinal round match left on Thursday, March 12 at 5:30pm at the Butler Middle School. The STEM Academy, Sullivan Middle School and Pyne Arts Magnet School will compete for the last spot in the finals!

The finals will be held Monday, March 16 at 5:30pm at the Butler.

post_text: Congratulations to Natalie Khattiya, 3rd grader at the Moody Elementary School, who has her art on display at the Young and Budding Artists exhibit at the Newburyport Art Association art gallery!
shared_text:
Moody Elementary School

Please join us tonight (Thursday, March 5th) at 5:30pm at the Butler Middle School for the final match of the preliminary rounds. The Pyne Arts, Robinson and Wang will compete for their placement in the Elimination Round next week.

Elimination Rounds will be held on Monday, March 9, Tuesday, March 10, and Thursday, March 12. All matches begin at 5:30pm and are held at the Butler Middle School.
Finals will be held on Monday, March 16th and will be broadcast live on TV.

post_text: Congrats to the Daley Middle School Knowledge Bowl team! Good luck to the rest of the teams competing in this week's preliminary round!
shared_text:
Daley Middle School
March 3 at 2:55 AM ·

The Daley Knowledge Bowl Team kicked off their competition season Monday night with a preliminary round match against the Sullivan and Bartlett schools. The Daley scored 275 points to capture first place on the night. The current events round was a highlight as Elizabeth Zhan, Sara Skaff, Jack Soucy, and Erin Shetler swept all 6 questions and earned a perfect score of 60. In the toss-up round, Evan Blaschke was quick on the buzzer and well supported by River Kelly and Rutt Kho. In the bonus toss-up round our youngest team member, 6th grader Dash Hanson had a clutch response in the science categories that enabled the team to earn bonus points. The team really saved their buzzer speed for the aptly named speed round, though, where they added 90 more points to the team score, due in large part to the multiple answers provided by Nana Opoku. These nine students represented the school with dignity and pride and they look forward to competing again next week in the semi-finals.

Congrats to the Daley Middle School Knowledge Bowl team! Good luck to the rest of the teams competing in this week's preliminary round!

The Daley scored 275 points to capture first place on the night. The current events round was a highlight as Elizabeth Zhan, Sara Skaff, Jack Soucy, and Erin Shetler swept all 6 questions and earned a perfect score of 60. In the toss-up round, Evan Blaschke was quick on the buzzer and well supported by River Kelly and Rutt Kho. In the bonus toss-up round our youngest team member, 6th grader Dash Hanson had a clutch response in the science categories that enabled the team to earn bonus points. The team really saved their buzzer speed for the aptly named speed round, though, where they added 90 more points to the team score, due in large part to the multiple answers provided by Nana Opoku. These nine students represented the school with dignity and pride and they look forward to competing again next week in the semi-finals.

post_text:
Knowledge Bowl is back! The second match of the preliminary round is this evening, Wednesday, March 4 at 5:30pm at the Butler Middle School. Here is a question from the first night of competition on Monday:

At Market Basket, it takes two employees 3 minutes to fill 10 bags of groceries. If we assume the employees work at the same rate, how long will it take one employee to fill 15 bags of groceries?

Let us know the answer in the comments section!

KNOWLEDGE BOWL IS BACK!

The first match of the Kathryn P. Stoklosa Knowledge Bowl kicked off Monday night with teams from the Bartlett, Daley and Sullivan middle schools competing in the preliminary round.

The Daley team scored 275 points, followed by the Sullivan with 185 and the Bartlett with 60. These scores will be seeded with the other middle school teams following the other two preliminary round matches this week.

Please join us tomorrow night (Wednesday, March 4) when we see teams from the Stoklosa, Butler and STEM Academy compete, and on Thursday, March 5 when we will see the Pyne Arts, Robinson and Wang teams face off. The semifinal round matches will be held next week on March 9, 10 and 12. The final will be held March 16.

All of the matches begin at 5:30pm and are held at the Butler Middle School auditorium.

post_text:
The safety of our students and staff is always our top priority within the Lowell Public Schools. In light of concerns over the recent global outbreak of Coronavirus (now known as COVID-19) and how it may impact our city and schools, we want to share this joint letter with you from the Lowell Public Schools and the City of Lowell Health Department: https://www.lowell.k12.ma.us/cms/lib/MA01907636/Centricity/Domain/4/Coronavirus%20Lowell%20Prevention%20Message.pdf

We are aware of a report that a patient at Lowell General Hospital is undergoing treatment in an isolated room to evaluate if they meet the criteria for COVID-19. As of posting this message, the immediate risk to all Lowell residents is still low, and there are still no confirmed cases in the city. We will continue to keep you updated with any new information we receive. If you have any questions in the meantime, please feel free to follow up with the Lowell Health Department, or your school's nurse.

LOWELL.K12.MA.US
www.lowell.k12.ma.us

post_text:
Former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld, a candidate for President in the Republican Primary, visited with Lowell High students last week, discussing his career and his campaign. Weld spoke with a group of students comprised of two AP US Government and Politics classes and two American Civics Past and Present classes. The visit was organized by LHS AP US Government and Politics teacher Nate Kraft, who invited every candidate running for president this election cycle to visit LHS. Earlier this fall, Joe Sestak, who was running in the Democratic Primary, also came and spoke with LHS students.

Take a look at some photos from Gov. Weld's visit to LHS. In the first photo he is posing with a LHS tie, which was presented to him when he arrived at the school. He is pictured (L-R) with LHS senior George Gikas, sophomore Natasha Watts, and senior Shaveen Gachau.

Lowell High Winter Sports MIAA Tournament Update:

BOTH BOYS BASKETBALL & HOCKEY ARE IN THE SECTIONAL SEMIFINALS!

LHS BOYS BASKETBALL
The top-seeded, still undefeated Lowell High boys' basketball team beat #8 Central Catholic 64-51 this past Friday night to advance to the semifinals of the MIAA Division 1 North playoffs. LHS will play #5 Cambridge Rindge & Latin tonight (Tuesday) at 7pm at Woburn High. The winner will go to the Division 1 North finals.

LHS BOYS HOCKEY
The ninth-seeded Lowell High boys' hockey team beat top-seeded Bedford 2-0 on Sunday to advance to the semifinals of the MIAA Division 3 North playoffs. LHS will play #13 Swampscott this Thursday at 5pm at the Chelmsford Forum. The winner will go to the Division 3 North finals.

Lowell Public Schools Preschool and Kindergarten registration period is coming up soon so we are holding an event to help families get ready! Our Preschool and Kindergarten Showcase Night is this Monday night, March 2 from 6:30 to 8:30pm at the McAuliffe Elementary School, located at 570 Beacon St.

Families will be able to find out more information about the registration process and how to enroll their child. Families will also be able to meet staff from each of our preschools and elementary schools, and meet community organizations who offer services for families. There will also be food and raffles. There is no cost to attend this event!

More details on the flyer...we hope to see you there!

(Flyers are posted in English, Spanish, Portuguese, Khmer and Swahili...please share with any relatives/neighbors with children eligible for preschool or kindergarten!)

More details on the flyer...we hope to see you there!

(Flyers are posted in English, Spanish, Portuguese, Khmer and Swahili...please share with any relatives/neighbors with children eligible for preschool or kindergarten!)

Our Preschool and Kindergarten Showcase Night is this Monday night, March 2 from 6:30 to 8:30pm at the McAuliffe Elementary School, located at 570 Beacon St.

Families will be able to find out more information about the registration process and how to enroll their child. Families will also be able to meet staff from each of our preschools and elementary schools, and meet community organizations who offer services for families. There will also be food and raffles. There is no cost to attend this event!

The ninth-seeded Lowell High boys' hockey team takes on #8 Somerville in the first round of the MIAA Division 3 North Sectional playoffs tonight (Thursday) at the Stoneham Arena. Puck drops at 8pm. Tickets are $8 for adults and $6 for students. Go LHS!

The winner of this game will take on top-seeded Bedford on March 1.

Here is the full Division 3 North bracket via the MIAA website: http://miaa.statebrackets.com/tmenu.cfm?tid=5501

post_text:
Congratulations to the Lowell High boys' indoor track team for winning the MIAA All-State Championship for the second straight season!

The MIAA Indoor Track & Field All-State Championship was held Saturday at the Reggie Lewis Track in Boston. The LHS boys' track/cross country program has now won 8 all-state titles since 2012 (3 in indoor track, 3 in cross country, and 2 in outdoor track).

Read more about their latest title in the Lowell Sun: https://www.lowellsun.com/2020/02/22/lowell-high-boys-defend-all-state-title/

(Photo courtesy of the MIAA on Twitter)

post_text: Who said learning can't be fun? Check out this great STEM activity at the Murkland School before the start of February vacation!
shared_text:
Murkland School
February 14 at 8:02 PM ·

Today's STEM Challenge was dynamic! Students designed skiers, bobsleds, and chairlifts to safely and quickly go down tracks. They worked through the engineering process with steady determination and came up with some efficient designs. Then, they raced against other classes and grades in the gym. It was quite the event!

post_text:
More than 70 students from seven Massachusetts schools, including the STEM Academy, were recently selected to present computer science prototypes to industry professionals during the Mass STEM Hub Computer Science Showcase. Two 7th grade students from the STEM Academy, Nicholas Touch and Destin Silvera, received the App Creators Innovation Award!

Read more about this accomplishment in the Lowell Sun: https://www.lowellsun.com/2020/02/12/lowell-students-showcase-computer-science-prototypes-to-industry-pros/

(In the photo STEM Academy students Nicholas Touch and Destin Silvera are pictured with STEM Academy teacher Erinn McLaughlin. Photo Courtesy of One8 Foundation.)

post_text:
Please be advised that the Lowell Public Schools will have a 2 hour delay on Thursday, February 13, 2020.

Each school will be opening 2 hours later than the normal starting time.

School buses have been scheduled to arrive at all bus stops 2 hours later.

It is important to stress that there is NO morning and NO afternoon half day Pre-K classes and breakfast will NOT be served in our schools today.

All full day Pre-K classes will be held and students in full day Pre-k classes should be at school 2 hours later than usual.
